message.content: This question requires some knowledge about the properties of bullet materials. The correct answer is (B) alloys. Alloys are a combination of metals, and when used to make bullets, they can be more difficult to trace than bullets made from a single metal such as lead. Option (A) is incorrect because metal alone can still be traceable. Option (C) is also incorrect because lead is a common material used in bullets and can be traced. Option (D), frozen water, is unrelated to bullet production and would not be used to make an untraceable bullet.

This question requires knowledge about the properties of bullets and their traceability. Option (D) is incorrect because frozen water, or ice, cannot be used to make bullets. Bullets are typically made of metal, usually lead or lead alloys, as indicated by option (C), which is the correct answer. Metal, option (A), is a general category that can include lead, but it is not specific enough to answer the question. Option (B) is also incorrect because alloys are mixtures of metals, which can be used to make bullets but are not the primary material used.

This question requires some understanding of the properties of bullets and how they are traced by forensics. An untraceable bullet refers to a bullet that cannot be linked to a specific firearm. Options (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect because they all involve materials commonly used in bullets that can be traced back to a specific firearm through ballistics analysis. Option (D) is correct because frozen water, also known as ice, can be used as a makeshift bullet in certain situations. Ice bullets are not commonly used and would be difficult to trace back to a specific firearm since they would melt upon impact.
